content:
image.png

image.png

Note: Corrections and comments are welcome.

Given an algebra (with unit) AAA and a product m:A⊗A→Am: A\otimes A\to Am:A⊗A→A given by m(a⊗a′)=aa′m(a\otimes a') = aa'm(a⊗a′)=aa′ (product in AAA), let III denote the kernel ker(m).\mathsf{ker}(m).ker(m).

The universal differential d~:A→I\tilde d: A\to Id~:A→I

d~:x↦1⊗x−x⊗1\tilde d: x\mapsto 1\otimes x - x\otimes 1d~:x↦1⊗x−x⊗1 (Note: Bourbaki has a sign difference, but I will use this convention.)

can be written as a (graded) commutator

d~:x↦[G~,x],\tilde d: x\mapsto [\tilde G,x],d~:x↦[G~,x],

where G~=1⊗1.\tilde G=1\otimes 1.G~=1⊗1.

d~\tilde dd~ generates III as a left AAA-module. If a=∑ixi⊗yi∈Ia = \sum_i x_i\otimes y_i\in Ia=∑i​xi​⊗yi​∈I, then m(a)=0m(a) = 0m(a)=0 by definition and

a=∑ixi⊗yi=∑ixi(1⊗yi−yi⊗1)=∑ixid~yi.\begin{aligned} a &= \sum_i x_i\otimes y_i \\ &= \sum_i x_i \left(1\otimes y_i - y_i\otimes 1\right) \\ &= \sum_i x_i \tilde d y_i.\end{aligned}a​=i∑​xi​⊗yi​=i∑​xi​(1⊗yi​−yi​⊗1)=i∑​xi​d~yi​.​
I love how Bourbaki spells out the proofs explicitly regardless how "obvious" they may be. Even mortals like me can follow :blush:

Similarly,

a=∑ixi⊗yi=∑i(xi⊗1−1⊗xi)yi=∑i−(d~xi)yi.\begin{aligned} a &= \sum_i x_i\otimes y_i \\ &= \sum_i \left(x_i\otimes 1 - 1\otimes x_i\right) y_i \\ &= \sum_i - (\tilde dx_i) y_i.\end{aligned}a​=i∑​xi​⊗yi​=i∑​(xi​⊗1−1⊗xi​)yi​=i∑​−(d~xi​)yi​.​

In particular, I guess this means

x⊗y∈I  ⟹  x⊗y=xd~y=−(d~x)y.x\otimes y\in I\implies x\otimes y = x \tilde d y = -(\tilde d x) y.x⊗y∈I⟹x⊗y=xd~y=−(d~x)y.

If f:I→Ef: I\to Ef:I→E is an AAA-bimodule morphism, then

d=f∘d~:A→Ed=f\circ\tilde d: A\to Ed=f∘d~:A→E

is also a derivation.

That makes sense. Given a bimodule morphism f:I→Ef:I\to Ef:I→E, you get a derivation d=f∘d~:A→E.d = f\circ\tilde d: A\to E.d=f∘d~:A→E.

The opposite direction is less clear to me despite staring at the Bourbaki paragraphs for a while :thinking:

Given a derivation d:A→Ed: A\to Ed:A→E, you get a unique bimodule morphism f:I→Ef: I\to Ef:I→E :thinking:

I guess the argument is that since

(x,y)↦xdy(x,y) \mapsto x d y(x,y)↦xdy

is bilinear, there is a unique linear map

g:A⊗A→Eg: A\otimes A\to Eg:A⊗A→E

and we need to show that ggg restricted to III is a bimodule morphism.
But doesn't that require that EEE is generated by ddd as a left AAA-module? :thinking:

It is clear to me that if x⊗y∈I,x\otimes y\in I,x⊗y∈I, then g(x⊗y)=xdy∈E,g(x\otimes y) = x dy\in E,g(x⊗y)=xdy∈E,

but can there be elements of EEE not of that form? :thinking:

Btw, I think the proof of AAA-bilinearity is cleaner to note that

∑ixid(yiy)=−∑i(dxi)yiy.\sum_i x_i d(y_i y) = -\sum_i (dx_i) y_i y.∑i​xi​d(yi​y)=−∑i​(dxi​)yi​y.

:nerd:

I think I get it.

g:A⊗A→Eg: A\otimes A\to Eg:A⊗A→E

is unique, so restricted to III, we have a unique AAA-bimodule morphism

g:I→Eg: I\to Eg:I→E

given by

g(∑ixi⊗yi):=∑ixidyi.g\left(\sum_i x_i\otimes y_i\right) := \sum_i x_i d y_i.g(∑i​xi​⊗yi​):=∑i​xi​dyi​.

Since ggg is an AAA-bimodule morphism, we have

g(∑ixi⊗yi)=g(∑ixid~yi)=∑ixig(d~yi),\begin{aligned} g\left(\sum_i x_i\otimes y_i\right) &= g\left(\sum_i x_i\tilde d y_i\right) \\ &= \sum_i x_i g(\tilde d y_i),\end{aligned}g(i∑​xi​⊗yi​)​=g(i∑​xi​d~yi​)=i∑​xi​g(d~yi​),​

so that

d=g∘d~.d = g\circ\tilde d.d=g∘d~.

Cool :sunglasses:

To summarize, given an AAA-bimodule morphism g:I→Eg: I\to Eg:I→E, we get a unique derivation d:A→Ed: A\to Ed:A→E given by

d:=g∘d~.d := g\circ\tilde d.d:=g∘d~.

Conversely, given a derivation d:A→Ed: A\to Ed:A→E, we get a unique AAA-bimodule morphism g:I→Eg: I\to Eg:I→E given by

g:∑ixi⊗yi↦∑ixidyi.g: \sum_i x_i\otimes y_i \mapsto \sum_i x_i d y_i.g:∑i​xi​⊗yi​↦∑i​xi​dyi​.

Yay! I understand the proof! :tada:

Next. Is there an arrow theoretic / functorial way to understand this?
Maybe that derivations out of A are represented by I?

I made some progress (at least for first order). The nLab has a nice diagram to represent kernels, so this universal derivation can be summarized by the commutative diagram:

image.png

where m:A⊗A→Am: A\otimes A\to Am:A⊗A→A is multiplication in AAA and Ω~1=ker(m)\tilde\Omega^1 = \mathsf{ker}(m)Ω~1=ker(m) and d=ϕ∘d~:A→Ω1d= \phi\circ \tilde d: A\to\Omega^1d=ϕ∘d~:A→Ω1 is any other derivation.
The morphisms are AAA-bimodule morphisms, so we must be sitting in the category of AAA-bimodules :thinking:

Extending to second order seems formally straighforward to write down:

image.png

The question is: What is Ω~1⊗Ω~1→Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1\otimes\tilde\Omega^1\to\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1⊗Ω~1→Ω~1?

I know what I want it to be, but I don't know how to motivate it. Maybe it is fine to define it and prove it works. That is probably justification enough :thinking:

A guiding principle should be (I believe):

a=∑ixi⊗yi⊗zi∈Ω~2  ⟹  a=∑ixidyidzi.a = \sum_i x_i\otimes y_i\otimes z_i\in\tilde\Omega^2\implies a = \sum_i x_i d y_i d z_i.a=∑i​xi​⊗yi​⊗zi​∈Ω~2⟹a=∑i​xi​dyi​dzi​.

As an intermediate step, we have a product

(A⊗A)⊗(A⊗A)→A⊗A⊗A(A\otimes A)\otimes (A\otimes A)\to A\otimes A\otimes A(A⊗A)⊗(A⊗A)→A⊗A⊗A

written as juxtaposition and given by

(w⊗x)(y⊗z)=w⊗(xy)⊗z.(w\otimes x)(y\otimes z) = w\otimes (xy)\otimes z.(w⊗x)(y⊗z)=w⊗(xy)⊗z.

This is similar to the composition of spans.

If w⊗x,y⊗z∈Ω~1w\otimes x, y\otimes z\in\tilde\Omega^1w⊗x,y⊗z∈Ω~1, then their product is zero if x⊗yx\otimes yx⊗y is also in Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 so we don't want that. In fact, we'll see later that we want x=yx = yx=y and we know x⊗x∉Ω~1.x\otimes x\not\in\tilde\Omega^1.x⊗x∈Ω~1.
There is one thing missing before we completely define Ω~1⊗Ω~1→Ω~1.\tilde\Omega^1\otimes\tilde\Omega^1\to\tilde\Omega^1.Ω~1⊗Ω~1→Ω~1.
Spolier: I think we want G~2=1⊗1⊗1=0.\tilde G^2 = 1\otimes 1\otimes 1 = 0.G~2=1⊗1⊗1=0.

The product m:Ω~1⊗Ω~1→Ω~1m: \tilde\Omega^1\otimes\tilde\Omega^1\to\tilde\Omega^1m:Ω~1⊗Ω~1→Ω~1 should be an AAA-bimodule morphism so

m(u(v⊗w)⊗(x⊗y)z)=u(m((v⊗w)⊗(x⊗y)))z.m\left(u(v\otimes w)\otimes(x\otimes y)z\right) = u \left(m\left((v\otimes w)\otimes(x\otimes y)\right)\right) z.m(u(v⊗w)⊗(x⊗y)z)=u(m((v⊗w)⊗(x⊗y)))z.

Eric Forgy said:

Spolier: I think we want G~2=1⊗1⊗1=0.\tilde G^2 = 1\otimes 1\otimes 1 = 0.G~2=1⊗1⊗1=0.

Maybe a better way to say it is we want

x⊗y∈Ω~1  ⟹  x⊗1⊗y=0.x\otimes y\in\tilde\Omega^1\implies x\otimes 1\otimes y = 0.x⊗y∈Ω~1⟹x⊗1⊗y=0.
(I think)

Put another way,

x⊗y,y⊗z∈Ω~1  ⟹  x⊗z∉Ω~1.x\otimes y, y\otimes z\in\tilde\Omega^1\implies x\otimes z\not\in\tilde\Omega^1.x⊗y,y⊗z∈Ω~1⟹x⊗z∈Ω~1.

Updated diagram to make that intermediate step more explicit:

image.png
I'm probably thinking about this all wrong.
